title: 111_s1959
content: The "Health Care Fraud Enforcement Act of 2009" enhances criminal laws related to health care fraud. The "Health Care Fraud Enforcement Act of 2009" enhances criminal laws related to health care fraud by defining Federal health care offenses and instructing the United States Sentencing Commission to review and amend sentencing guidelines for individuals convicted of such offenses. The "Health Care Fraud Enforcement Act of 2009" aims to enhance criminal laws related to health care fraud by establishing guidelines for fraudulent bill amounts submitted to Government health care programs as evidence of intended loss by defendants. It also proposes amendments to the Federal Sentencing Guidelines, including level increases for offenders involved in health care offenses with specific loss amounts. The "Health Care Fraud Enforcement Act of 2009" proposes enhancements to criminal laws regarding health care fraud, including guidelines for fraudulent bill amounts in Government health care programs. It suggests amendments to the Federal Sentencing Guidelines, such as level increases for offenders based on specific loss amounts. The United States Sentencing Commission must ensure that Federal Sentencing Guidelines reflect the seriousness of health care fraud and consult with various stakeholders. The United States Sentencing Commission must ensure that Federal Sentencing Guidelines for health care fraud reflect seriousness, consistency with other directives, account for circumstances, make necessary changes, and meet sentencing purposes. Section 1347 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include an intent requirement for health care fraud. Title 18, United States Code is amended to include provisions regarding violations without actual knowledge or specific intent. The Social Security Act is also amended to include penalties for false claims related to kickbacks. Additionally, Section 24(a) of title 18 is amended to address health care fraud offenses. The United States Code is amended to include provisions for violations without specific intent. This includes penalties for false claims related to kickbacks and addresses health care fraud offenses. The United States Code is amended to include subpoena authority relating to health care under the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 and the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act. The Attorney General or any officer of the Department of Justice can subpoena institutions and documents related to investigations under the Act to ensure constitutional rights are not violated. Subpoenas must be signed by the Attorney General or designated officer. The Attorney General or designated officers can issue subpoenas to institutions for documents related to investigations under the Act. Failure to comply may result in a court order for enforcement. Subpoenaed records and information are protected under the law. The assurance report obtained under a subpoena may only be used to protect the rights of individuals in institutions, cannot be transmitted for any other purpose, and must be redacted to prevent disclosure of personally identifiable information. SEC. 4. ADDITIONAL AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS TO THE DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE FOR CRIMINAL AND CIVIL ENFORCEMENT OF HEALTH CARE FRAUD. Authorization is given to the Attorney General for $20,000,000 annually from 2011 to 2016 for investigations, prosecutions, and proceedings related to fraud in health care benefit programs. The allocation breakdown includes $10,000,000 for U.S. attorneys' offices, $5,000,000 for the Criminal Division, and $5,000,000 for the Civil Division of the Department of Justice.
